questions.question: What is the Coriolis component of acceleration?

answers.c: The additional acceleration due to relative motion in a rotating system

explanations.a: Radial acceleration is due to the change in direction toward the center of rotation.
explanations.b: Tangential acceleration occurs when angular speed changes.
explanations.c: Coriolis acceleration arises because of relative motion within a rotating frame.
explanations.d: Gravitational acceleration is unrelated to rotational frame effects.

questions.question: Which component is NOT part of a point's total absolute acceleration?

explanations.a: Centripetal acceleration is required for circular motion.
explanations.b: Gravitational acceleration is external and unrelated to absolute acceleration in rotating systems.
explanations.c: Tangential acceleration arises from changing angular speed.
explanations.d: Coriolis acceleration is an additional component in rotational frames.

questions.question: In which direction does the Coriolis acceleration act?

answers.c: Perpendicular to both radial and angular velocity

explanations.a: Coriolis acceleration does not align with radial velocity.
explanations.b: It does not oppose the radial velocity.
explanations.c: It always acts perpendicular to both radial motion and angular velocity.
explanations.d: It does not act along the rotation axis.

explanations.a: Linear motion in a non-inertial frame alone does not cause Coriolis acceleration.
explanations.b: Rotational motion in an inertial frame does not generate Coriolis effects.
explanations.c: Coriolis acceleration appears when an object moves radially inside a rotating frame.
explanations.d: Constant velocity in a stationary system has no Coriolis effect.

questions.question: Which application uses Coriolis effect to measure mass flow rate?

explanations.a: Centrifugal pumps do not use Coriolis effect.
explanations.b: Venturi meters work on pressure difference, not Coriolis force.
explanations.c: Pitot tubes measure velocity using stagnation pressure.
explanations.d: Coriolis flow meters directly use vibration-induced Coriolis forces to find mass flow rate.

explanations.d: m/s² is acceleration, not angular velocity.

questions.question: What happens to ac when radial velocity increases?

explanations.a: Coriolis acceleration does not decrease with radial velocity.
explanations.c: Coriolis acceleration is directly proportional to radial velocity.
explanations.d: It is not zero unless radial velocity is zero.

questions.question: What happens to ac if angular velocity is doubled?

explanations.a: Coriolis acceleration depends linearly on angular velocity.
explanations.c: Doubling angular velocity doubles Coriolis acceleration.
explanations.d: It does not increase by four times (that applies to centripetal acceleration).
